We are now able to tap into the enormous amount of knowledge of people all over the world, which allows us to see what is really going on in countries like @ LOCATION2, where the media is seen as a betrayal. What are we doing now that governments are starting to censor the internet? Let's start by examining an argument that has been talked about for a long time: the censorship of libraries. Today, it is almost a requirement for cities to have public libraries to be considered as real cities. Public libraries, and the funding they require, are nowhere to be found in @ ORGANIZATION1. However, they have taken a place in our neighborhoods which have made them indefinite sources of knowledge and culture. Libraries are generally family institutions, and as publicly funded, they are held to uphold the moral and ethical standards of those who live in the area. This means that there is not a " national list of banned books ", but that there are many discrepancies across @ LOCATION1 in the banning of books. The introduction of new, fresh and new literary materials to the library means that more people will return to the library, whether they are young adults or older people trying to get in touch with the world today. Censorship is acceptable under certain circumstances, but what is censored should not be decided by the government. First of all, freedom of speech is very important to the people at @ LOCATION1. If this freedom were to be taken away, it would certainly not go unnoticed. When books, music, films and magazines are censored, the author's freedom of expression is diminished. For example, what if an atheist wrote a book that said @ CAPS1 was not real? Many @ CAPS2 would like to remove this book from the shelves of all libraries. Just because a group of people don't like the subject, message, or theme of a book doesn't mean they have to pull out of a library. A library is a place where all books have a chance to be read, not a place where people can choose what they want because of their beliefs. Second, authors have the right to express their thoughts and to have their works recognized by the public as well. Of course, there will be books that are more popular than others, but at the same time there will also be books that will be overlooked not because of the quality of the writing but because of the subject that the author has chosen. to treat. There is no reason for an entire community to ignore an author's work just because a large group of people disagree with what they are saying. In that little group of people who weren't trying to get rid of this book, you would find a number of people who would read the book. Just because a majority does not like the subject of the book does not mean that the minority should have the book withdrawn. The author has the right to what he has written and must have the possibility of having his work recognized. Finally, censorship can also be a good thing in certain circumstances. It just depends on how the censorship is used. For example, many parents do not want their children to read, listen to, or watch certain things. The child's parents should be able to decide what a child can read, listen to or watch, not a large group of people. Many parents have different standards and what some parents find acceptable for their children @ MONTH1 scares others. Thus, there could never be a standard set for what is acceptable and not acceptable without creating a great amount of controversy. Once that child becomes an adult, he has full rights to decide what he wants from a library. However, there should be some limitations. For example, a person must be seventeen years of age or older to rent a movie rated " @ CAPS3 ". This is the same age a person must be to enter a movie rated '@ CAPS3' without parental supervision. Some of the age limits throughout society should be set in libraries, but other than that the decisions should be left to the person. Censorship in libraries will always change. Sometimes it will be in effect while at other times it will not. The folks at @ LOCATION1 have freedom of expression and removing books from libraries partially takes away that right. The author should have the right to have his book also recognized by the public and kept on the shelves. Censorship should be decided by the person themselves and should not be decided for them. Parents should have a say in what their children read and should not have this decision made by others

Censorship In a library, there is a plethora of books to choose from. Books ranging from children to difficult adults. It's good to know that you have a lot of options and the freedom to choose which book you want to read. Censorship is the censorship of a piece of material so that it is not legally or publicly available. If a book were censored for its content, it would call into question other books or media that relate to it. I believe that if books, magazines, movies, etc. were censored in a library, the material would not stand a chance of being exposed to people. Some people write books and songs to express themselves or to earn money. If a book is removed from a library, other libraries will have to remove it as well, and other libraries will not purchase it. Some people just want to express their ideas and share their message with other people. Censorship somehow stops the flow of what people are learning. Another part of censorship is knowing where to draw the line of what is offensive enough to be censored. If a book is pulled from the library for its content, people will be asking why it was pulled. It makes people wonder what other books are offensive as well. The reason why a book is deleted can be related to another book and can also lead to the deletion of that one. Since censorship is probably mostly opinion, there's no clear line between what can stay on the shelf and what can't. With censorship, you only deprive people of freedom of the press. If a publisher accepts a medium only to be censored later, it may mean that we need new publishers, or that they are also interested in bringing what people have to say to the world known. The censorship limit is very stubborn and should not be dictated by one group. When a book is taken down, it only challenges others. These are my beliefs about censorship in the library

Censorship is a big controversy in modern society due to the number of opinions conveyed by all the new media in the modern world. When a person has an opinion, they tend to want to share it with the world or to defend it against those who oppose their opinion. Some people don't always like what is said or take offense at the way it is presented, which causes the government, or any authority, to remove or replace those words, photos, words or films from an audience. selected, like children. , or the general public. It is censorship and it has sparked a lot of debate about what is acceptable in society's media. I think the censorship is bad. This violates the peoples' right of free expression @ CAPS1. When a person has an opinion, he has the right to express it as he wishes. The authorities should in no way be involved in what someone writes, sings, creates, etc. Censorship takes away the integrity and purity of a human's thoughts. Who should say what can and cannot be said? Are we just letting the government tell us what we can say and what is illegal? Do we stop expressing ourselves the way we want because it's not appropriate? No. We as a people must be free to say whatever we want in our stories and songs, as well as in movies and other media. If a person does not like what he sees, he can turn away from it or he has the right to denounce it in his own way; but they do not have the right to oppress. They should respond, get their message across, and try to gain support, not control. Censorship is not good for any society. People want to say what they want and they have a right to do so. Censorship is not a solution to discrimination or anger, it is only fuel. Other organizations tell us what books we can and can't read, what video games we can and can't play, and what items we can and can't buy. She says there are some books that most people would find a little graphic or shocking, but we can't take these books off the shelf because eventually there would be no more books to read. I agree with her in the sense that we cannot remove certain books from the shelves of our library. We can't take them off the shelves because that would be taboo in many ways. This would be stepping into hot water because people would violate the press freedom of the authors, who would decide what material is good or bad, and how far it is too far in censorship. These are just a few of the many reasons it is wrong. To take certain books off the shelves would be against our constitution. The @ CAPS3 @ CAPS4 gives all citizens @ CAPS5 the freedom of the press. This means that they can write whatever they want without having to worry about the opinions of the government or the citizens. If we start removing certain books from library shelves because they @ MONTH1 contain some controversial material, we are violating their natural right. Which brings me to my next point: if we allow censorship, who should be responsible? So many people want to include their opinions on what is right and what is wrong. So who are we supposed to believe? On person @ MONTH1 thinks something is out of place, but the person standing next to her would think it's ordinary. This is what makes this country great. We are a mixture of many different ideas that work together for a common goal. If the government assigned someone to censor books, magazines or music, there would be an uproar. How can a person tell if something is wrong? What if someone was allowed to censor things, what would be included? How far is it? It is a difficult question to ask. If we were to allow one person to judge things, what would be included? Would the judgment stop at books, films and music alone? Or would it extend to the judgment of clothes and lifestyles? If we apply this system of censorship, our life will become a great judgment. Self-expression would go out the window because people were afraid of being judged " inappropriate ". Our world would become a puzzle of trying to fit in and not be noticed, rather than stand out and move the human race forward. There will always be people who disagree with things. Katherine Paterson, an author, said if all reading or listening material was removed, nothing would be left. I totally agree with this statement. If someone finds an aspect of a job offensive, that does not allow the job to be prohibited or discarded. I believe that offensive material should not be removed for the following reasons : it removes the feelings of the author, nothing will be left on the shelves, and there is no line defining what is or is not offensive. Now I understand that there are a large number of people who are against my position. I assure them that I understand these feelings. Some audiences think that removing offensive material is good because it protects the ears of those who can't handle the verb or context. Others @ MONTH1 feel that the sensitive audience @ MONTH1 is not comfortable with text. In addition, many people believe that exposing people to violent, risky and dangerous behavior will cause the same behavior in young children. The censorship I'm talking about relates specifically to censorship in libraries. There are three main reasons why libraries shouldn't be censored. When the librarian told us, we were upset because we girls loved to read these books. The librarian at the time thought they were appropriate and really didn't want to take them out of the library. So she had a great idea. She took these books, the ones people were complaining about, and put them on their own special shelf behind her desk. If you wanted one of these books, you had to tell your parents about it or bring a note that you were allowed to read the book. It was a really good idea, because if your parents wouldn't allow you to read them, you weren't tempted to get one, and you wouldn't even see them. Should public libraries censor some of the books, films and music they display? In my opinion, they shouldn't have to. As people, we have the right to learn, read, and expand our minds in any way that we think is appropriate for us. There are three main reasons why I think “ offensive ” writing, movies and music should be allowed in public libraries. One of the reasons they shouldn't be doing this is because people have written and spoken throughout history; therefore, there are too many parts that we would have to get rid of in order to eliminate them all. The second reason is that people have different opinions about what is “offensive” and what is not. The third reason that will be explained is that people will be exposed to whatever you are trying to hide, if not through the art of music, movies, or books, then through the real world we live in. Throughout history, mankind has written things down to document experiences, events, and ideas that have occurred throughout history. With these experiences come profanity, sexuality, death, and many situations that the public eye might consider “offensive”. If you were to try to delete these songs, one would destroy a lot of history for you, and two there are way too many books, movies, and music tracks you would have to get rid of. In almost all art forms, there is a point to something negative. If you were to remove them, you would end up with very few, if any, pounds. The second reason is that people have different opinions about what is bad and what is not. For example, I was on a group trip with all the other students in the group, and along the way, we made a movie. We ended up having to shut down the movie because one parent found it inappropriate. Although this parent didn't like it, other parents were upset that we turned it off because they saw nothing wrong with it. The same rules apply to books and music. It all depends on personal opinions as to whether it is " offensive " or not. The third reason is that people will experience all of the things you are trying to hide. If you take it out of the library, you'll hear about it on the news, on the radio, in a restaurant, in schools, just about anywhere. Taking the pieces out of the library will be useless in the long run. For example, people want to release a book called " The @ CAPS1 of @ ORGANIZATION1 " because it uses the word " nigger " in the story over and over. There are a lot of people who think that it is not suitable enough to be taught in school. On top of that, they want to get rid of all the books that say "nigger" and replace them with books that say "slave" instead. In my opinion, that would be a stupid thing to do, as it takes away the authenticity and effectiveness of the book. In the book, when they use the word, it's very powerful and thought-provoking. If you replace it with " slave, " that statement or passage loses its power over its readers. In conclusion, I firmly believe that libraries should not have to remove “ offensive ” books, music or films . If that happened, we would be removing some of our history and knowledge. With that, if we do, how will we know which books to release, if everyone has a different opinion on what is “ offensive ” and what is not. Finally, if we do, it won't solve anything. People in today's society will always be mean, always do sexual things, people will always use harsh language, and people will always be subjected to “ offensive ” actions . This is the society we live in and people will have to accept this fact. That's why I think we need to keep all the “ offensive ” pieces that we have, that way people reading them could be ready for the real world once they touch them.

Cool the @ CAPS1: @ CAPS2 and @ CAPS3 from the book @ PERSON1 _________ Censorship in public libraries would be an insult to the institution. A library, a citadel of knowledge, should not be bound by a society as to the knowledge it can transmit. One of the points of a library, intended for researchers, is to offer information to be sought: for those who cannot find the information at home without fear, for those who cannot ask their questions. without retaliation, the library is a pillar of security. Books are incapable of judgment. To censor books in a library is to undermine human progress. A freedom of thought and a freedom of the press, present within our nation and more and more present around @ CAPS5, exclude the idea of this censorship. If a book is subject to criticism or opposition, aren't all books worth the same? Valuing one opinion or perspective less than another is to demean the whole culture out of which libraries are born. Libraries are a common institution, open to all points of view and all writings. The point of bringing books together under one roof is to assimilate them and give them all equal status as literature or scholarly work. In my personal experience, censorship in the library cost me precious time and robbed me of parts of my life. Growing up in a small town, where ideas of gender and sexuality were fairly firmly entrenched, any dissenting opinion research was often unsuccessful. When I visited my school library, as a child looking for answers about my sexuality, I found little help. Around the library were a thousand stories of a man and a woman falling in love, but I never found a fairy tale of two princes. It wasn't until I left school that I found out that such books existed in my old school library, but they were being pulled, taken from the shelves, restricted. More insulting than finding books on @ CAPS4's issues completely unrepresented was to find that they were dealt with so separately. This is where the problem lies. Some people believe that if minority opinions or values are not represented, they will disappear. This is the purpose of censorship: to ignore a problem or a choice of life until extinction. But books cannot shout their values. They can't shove information down our throats. Books must be read, we must give our consent to their knowledge. Unlike an advertisement that might surprise us, we have to pick up a book and open it to receive his advice. If my library had done its job and given me the advice I was looking for, I would have grown much easier. I would not only have learned to express myself and accept myself, but I might also have grown up to accept others more easily. Over the past few years, with the effects of @ CAPS5 @ CAPS6 @ CAPS7 reaching the last generation, @ LOCATION1 has sought ways to honor the victims of @ CAPS8 and @ CAPS9 violence. What the country is seeing, however, is that it cannot effectively commemorate tragedies. As they try to build a monument, government and culture find they don't have much to do. The products of the murder and the fire-burning created a void, a void. As such, the architects created what @ MONTH1 is called “anti-monuments,” commemorating a void to posterity to commemorate what has been lost. One of the most powerful, to me at least, appears in the form of a negative shelf: a solid wall, with gaping holes in the shape of a book spine, spanning the rows. This is the knowledge lost by burning books. We cannot even describe what is lost, because the knowledge is gone. We have to ask ourselves, what are we missing? What views, what prose, what beauty has taken hold of us as we continue to live, without ever having the chance to see it? This is the effect of library censorship. To remove a book from its natural and legitimate place on a shelf is to ignite its words. Once he's gone, he'll be forgotten. To protect our posterity, to enlighten our descendants, we must work to preserve any books, any books that seem offensive, or disgusting, or brave, or new. Let the reader decide its value. Let the person looking for answers take it or leave it behind. Give the book a chance because @ MONTH1 has a power that is unrealized. Leave the libraries as they are, as monuments of the preservation and advancement of knowledge and wisdom.

Censorship is a subject on which he has taken a strong stand. If a person dislikes the content of a text, that person might find themselves saying that they have the right to refrain from being able to display that text in a library, public place, or online source. But what about other people? Shouldn't they have their say too? Let's say that " person 1 " does not agree with the language of a text, but " person two ", perhaps. Who has the advantage in the @ CAPS1 situation ? Freedom of speech and expression are two factors that are highly valued, and perhaps even sometimes ignored in our society. In the case of @ CAPS1, "person one" and "person two" have the right to say and think what they think about the text. Should " person 1 " always have the right to say that the @ CAPS1 text does not belong to a public place ? Now, if every person had the right to take something away from the public that they didn't agree with, there would be nothing left. In such a large and diverse society, there is bound to be at least one person who does not agree with the content of a certain material in every lyrics, magazine, book and text available. Some might say that @ CAPS1 is unfair to this group who disagree with the content of a document. But how is that fair to the other group that is actually okay with this material ? Freedom of speech and expression is still not excluded from this group which does not agree with such material. This group is always allowed to express their opinions and is supportive of that particular material, as well as people who agree with the material. Take iTunes for example. If there is a song whose language and / or content could be considered disrespectful to a person, there is a red tag next to the song that says " explecit ". @ CAPS1 is an indicator that a person who might find foul language offensive, such a person should not purchase this song. There is also the compromise. Quite often if a song is tagged as " explecit " it is usually an alternative of the same song. That same song is then tagged with a gray tag saying " clean ". A "clean" song simply means that the song is still the same, but content considered disrespectful is removed, or deleted and replaced with different words that are not considered disrespectful. Both parties are now happy with what is called: the happy median. Take movies as another example. Movies are classified according to their content. The higher the score, the more explicit such a film is. Along with the rating, there is an explanation as to why this movie is rated the way it is. If you are a person who pays attention to seeing things that go against your own opinions and beliefs, then by seeing the assessment and explanation, that person knows that the @ CAPS1 material is not for them. . Again, the happy median. For each given case of a group of people who disagree with the terms of a certain content, the alternative group should also be considered. Both parties in the @ CAPS1 case are still able to say and express their own opinions. So, should the @ CAPS1 context be removed from public view because a certain group of people disagree with the content it contains ? No. However, one should keep in mind the views and opinions that each person has about this material, and that person should always be respected for their perspective on this material.

Censorship is a word that provokes a lot of arguments in today's society. People have vastly different views on censorship around the world. In some countries, @ CAPS4 dictators allow their citizens to have Internet access to watch the news or, in some more extreme cases, @ CAPS4 even to watch television. Most of the time, they do it because @ CAPS4 wants the citizens of their country to know what is going on in the world. It creates a " fish bowl " environment, which means that people in other countries see all the problems in this country, but people in the country have no idea what is going on around them. . While we don't always see censorship in such an extreme sense, it still plays an important role in society today. Everything from music on the radio to military files is censored. Think about it, how often can you listen to a song on the radio that has all of the original words still intact ? Censorship disputes have been coming and going for years without really making much headway. Either side of the argument, whether for or against censorship, is almost entirely opinionated. No one can say for sure that censorship is completely necessary or @ CAPS4. It's just too difficult to determine who really is the most convincing opinion. In my opinion, I don't think anything should be conspired, if the author of a show @ CAPS1 throws a vulgar word, it is probably for the effect it has on people to show emotions. . The same goes for songs, when an artist writes the lyrics to a song, they're trying to get a point across and they're using certain words that get their point across more effectively or dramatically. There is an alternative to censoring all of these things, rather than "ruining" everyone's fun, just don't let your kids watch this show. In @ LOCATION1 today we have something called freedom, we exercise this right every day with what we wear and what we say. I think we should take that freedom and apply it to censorship. Instead of complaining about violence in movies and sex on @ CAPS1, you can just make the decision to @ CAPS4 to watch this kind of show. Everyone has the opportunity to say NO; if you don't want to hear or see something, just pick something else to watch, or even do something completely different. You DO @ CAPS4 have to do anything you don't want to do. This is an easy fix, all you have to do is exercise any right that you have had from the day you were born and just say no I don't want to do this. It seems that inappropriate materials are found all over the world today. In magazines, in books, in music lyrics, the possibilities for sneaking up on offensive references are endless, and they certainly appear everywhere these days. We all have different morals, values and perceptions of what is right and what is wrong; everyone is different. Perhaps it is your religion or your culture that distances you from these materials. But why should your values and beliefs dictate what another person can or cannot get from their library ? I know I'm not speaking for myself when I say I would be very bored if I couldn't get the books or materials that I wanted or needed just because the person next to me didn't disagree with what is found through searching this. I think some things should be separated from other parts of the libraries. For example, books that might be deemed offensive to children should be kept away from places where children can choose items from a library. This is quite understandable. But when things get deleted because some people disagree with them or find them offensive, that's when things go too far. This nation was built on the basis of the freedom for what you believe in. So why should we force others to believe something we mean? Just because I find something offensive doesn't mean the person next to me is doing it, which is fine with me. This is his personal opinion, and what I believe shouldn't prevent him from learning what he would like to do. One way to solve this problem would be to separate things that could possibly be found offensive in another section of the library and put up a sign or paper stating what exactly can be found in that section. In conclusion, no, I don't think libraries should be censored. If someone told me that I look like I've lost weight, I would find it shocking. The person wouldn't have meant it that way, however. Although I would have found it a bit rude, another person @ MONTH1 thought it was a nice compliment. With this logic, can we really conclude that something is really offensive? By saying something is offensive, you are expressing your own opinion. Even if they are not the same as those of others, everyone is entitled to their own opinions; equality is something that most people find very important. For this reason, the offensive definition of one person should not be higher than that of another. If we were to rid libraries of "offensive" material, that is exactly what you would be doing; you would make the definition of an offensive person superior to that of another person. I also think that libraries shouldn't get rid of “offensive” material, because in doing so they would probably get rid of a lot of interesting material. Let's use my religious beliefs for an example. I am @ CAPS1 @ CAPS2. Basically I don't believe in '@ CAPS3'. If someone wrote a book about my religion, I would find it interesting. Some @ CAPS4 @ MONTH1 find this offensive, however. So if a library got rid of this book because someone found it offensive, I wouldn't want to go there that often. When I go to a library, I want to find a book that I would like to read. If all material deemed offensive was removed from the library, would there really be anything left? If so, I doubt that many people find it interesting. I also believe so because by taking a book off the shelf because you find it offensive, wouldn't you be offending the author? As I said before, everyone is entitled to their own opinions. For this reason, libraries should allow authors to express themselves. By removing their books from the shelves, you will be offending them. They took their time and effort to think over and write this book, and if you offend them by taking it off the shelf, you would be defeating the very purpose of taking it off the shelf. In conclusion, I believe that nothing can really be defined as offensive. In addition, people should be able to express themselves. Therefore, libraries should not attempt to clear their shelves of " offensive " material.

@ NUM1ed Censorship of certain media is such a controversial subject. Whether or not a certain element is considered offensive and should be censored or not is more often opinionated than logically opposed, as it all really depends on someone's opinion on that issue. It is too difficult for most people to put themselves in someone else's shoes or be persuaded from a point of view different from their own or even to escape pressure from the general public to consider something else. . Things are censored for many reasons too! Sometimes they are just so intentionally offensive that the writer or producer perhaps wishes them censored or appreciates controversy, or that a new point of view or opinion is so radical and against a majority of the population that 'he's just considered offensive because he's so different. Well, when does someone have the right to take a song off the air or take a book off the shelf for good ? The first thing that needs to be considered is whether or not something is offensive. There are extremes in the media where you sometimes have to ask yourself, " @ CAPS1 were they thinking when they did this ?" " A film so outrageously graphic or violent is a good example (although the same can happen in the books, just with words instead of pictures). At the same time if anything you might think of as unnecessary gore in a movie might be right @ CAPS1 I can't wait to see when I go to the movies - everything is opinionated ! Another interesting idea is that someone could come up with a revolutionary and radical scientific theory and write an entire novel or film a documentary explaining all of this, but some groups of people might claim that this offends them. However, we could investigate this theory ourselves and not be offended in the slightest. It's understandable though, people grow up in an environment that has its own set of ethics and principles, and people will honestly believe them and likely stick to these fundamentals throughout their lives. If you go against the beliefs of someone who is so dear to him like that, it will of course be offensive to him. Does this mean that something should be censored just because it offends a few groups in a population? Whether something should be taken from public access is left to the opinion of the general public itself. Public opinion is created by current times, trends, ethics and issues. When something goes against too many of these things, people get upset. If most people are upset about something, it will probably start to disappear from their sight. It's bad for business, and libraries are already losing customers because most people no longer want to read with everything you can do otherwise. Some things can just put a bad taste in your mouth, and if someone has it too often when they go to a library, they probably won't go. So when it comes to censorship in libraries, or anywhere, it's just a bunch of opinions. If the general public doesn't like something, it will stop showing up. Some books or other media call for controversy over many topics, while others unintentionally go against certain groups of people. People's beliefs are determined by where and when they grew up, and they will hold onto these things for life. If anything goes against these, people will be offended, and if enough people are upset, it will be taken away from them.

Therefore, finding an offensive or inappropriate book does not entitle everyone to take this privilege away. Books found to be offensive to one person might have a completely different impact on the next reader; some @ MONTH1 even find the books relevant. Although this book contains a scene of rape and many other inappropriate events that this woman succumbed to throughout her life. Even so, it is still on the college suggested reading list for classes @ CAPS2 @ CAPS3 @ CAPS4. If all readers could look beyond the surface among these scenes, fewer books would be considered when removing from the shelves. A person's negative interpretation of a novel affects everyone's right to censorship in libraries. Readers are fully warned in advance of the maturity of the content. Books are categorized, reviewed, summarized (back cover summary) and even sorted in a library. If you find an offensive book, look in another section. Books are also sorted by genre for this reason; different genres appeal to different people. This also applies to the maturity of the reader. The books are sorted based on what appeals to which age. If you find a book offensive, instead of removing it completely from the shelf, look for a youth section or a completely different genre. If someone finds the book offensive, the fault is not that the book is there, but that the person is in the wrong section. The main problem with censorship of books in libraries is not the content, but the way in which interpretations differ from such content. On this issue, the opinions of other readers on specific deleted books are drastically overlooked. Complaining about the contents of a book automatically gives someone else the right to protect the contents of the book. There are several reasons to support this claim, including a specific quote from author Katherine Paterson. People build their character through their reactions to the way people treat them. For example, in life someone @ MONTH1 offends another person, but that doesn't mean the offender is going to go away after doing so. How does this relate to libraries, you might ask ? Books and movies don't need to be taken from library shelves if they are found to be offensive, because there is a lot in the real world that is offensive. It's your choice in what you want to read, listen to or watch. Just because you @ MONTH1 have the opportunity to verify something that you don't think is appropriate or offensive, doesn't mean you should verify it. Some people @ MONTH1 like to read or watch shocking things. You @ MONTH1 would like to argue, "But I don't want my kids exposed to such offensive content." That is why most public libraries are divided into sections for children and adults. If you happen to come across an offensive book in the children's section, don't let your child check it out. It's that simple. Trying to remove the book from the shelf or complaining about it would only take longer. The quote: “ We can all think of a book that we hope our children or any other child will have removed from the shelves. But if I have the right to take this book off the shelf - this job that I hate - then you have the exact same right and everyone else too. And then we don't have any more books on the shelves for any of us, ”by Katherine Paterson, is a perfect example to conclude on why books should not be taken off the shelves. She says if one person is allowed to take a book away, then anyone else will be able to have that ability as well. Therefore, a book that @ MONTH1 does not offend you at all could be taken off the shelf because someone else does not approve of it. Finally, there would be no more books. In conclusion, if there are any books, music, movies, or magazines that offend you, just don't check them out. You don't need to get rid of them because someone else @ MONTH1 wants to check them out

Among many overdue materials, movies have ratings, just as music has “ beeps ”. The films are classified '@ CAPS1' for all audiences, '@ CAPS2' for parental guidance, '@ NUM1' for parental guidance for ages @ NUM2 and over, and finally '@ CAPS3' meaning that any person less than @ NUM3 is either suggested or required to have an adult present when viewing the film. At home, ratings are all based on parent preference. In the cinema, restrictions become a kind of law. Anyone under the age of thirteen is not permitted to view a “@ NUM1” or “@ CAPS3” movie unless accompanied by an adult (anyone @ NUM5 or more). Anyone who is not @ NUM3 or older @ MONTH1 will not enter a movie rated '@ CAPS3' unless accompanied by someone @ NUM7 or older. Depending on where you are, the @ MONTH1 restrictions will be more or less severe. Ultimately, the scoring system is about forcing parents to choose what is appropriate and what is not for their child. As for the music on the radio, all the "bad words" are "beeped". If a person wants to buy their own music, artists are required to make two of the same album, one with censors and one without. Thus creating a decision generally for the parents, generally assuming that they are the ones who only want the album or the music for their child. When it comes to books, there is no ranking, just genres that let the reader know who the author's intended audience is. Genre types include “ adults ”, “ young adults ” and “ children ” sections in libraries and bookstores. Just like music and television, the final choice of purchase is entirely up to the parents. And then we don't have any more books on the shelf for any of us. @ CAPS1 was cited by an author named Katherine Paterson. I don't believe that certain materials such as books should be taken off the shelves under any circumstances. Everyone is entitled to their own opinion on certain materials. There will always be something you don't approve of. Just because you don't approve of it doesn't mean that not everyone approves of it. Authors write books for a reason, musicians write music for a reason, people make movies and magazines for a reason. What gives anyone the right to take something someone has done and ban them from the rest of the world for being offensive ? Books are there to help us become more educated and more open-minded to different thoughts and ideas. We shouldn't just ban them because they offend some people. If you don't like a book because it offends you, then don't read it. It's as simple as that. If people keep removing books because they are offensive, then there will be no more books to read.
If someone is looking for an offensive book, they will find it, whether they are collecting dust on a library shelf or whether it is brand new in a bookstore. The same goes for an offensive @ CAPS1, magazine or movie. Removing offensive items from library shelves will only cause people looking for those items to look elsewhere. Different people have different opinions about what is offensive and what is not. The @ CAPS2 @ CAPS3 is an example of a controversial book that many people thought was offensive to their religious beliefs. While many people found The @ CAPS2 @ CAPS3 offensive, others liked the story. If the book had been taken from libraries because some people found it offensive, then others who really enjoyed the book would not have been able to read it. Another reason why libraries should not remove offensive items from their shelves is that, most likely, the entire book, magazine, movie, etc. is not offensive from start to finish. Even if a movie contains an offensive scene, the rest of the movie could be a great story that a lot of people would benefit from seeing. It's the same idea with a book or a magazine. There are @ MONTH1 a few offensive chapters or one or two offensive articles, but very rarely will you find an offensive book, movie or magazine throughout. Of course, there are still some offensive elements that would be bad for young children to see, even with one or two offensive scenes, chapters or articles. There are simpler solutions to this problem than having to completely remove items from shelves. One solution to this problem could be for libraries to set age limits for certain articles, so that younger people cannot view material that is too inappropriate. Dear Editor-in-Chief I recently encountered a situation that made me quite uncomfortable in my local library, I saw a rather graphic magazine displayed in front of the entire library. Now I know that these magazines are, for some, a point of interest, but for others, they seem a little rude. It has also come to my attention that magazines are not the only form of rude merchandise on individuals at our local libraries. They're also littered with movies, books, graphic posters, and what I find to be explicit music. I know it would be unreasonable of me to request the removal of the murchandise, but I would like to post a compromise that might come into play. What I believe to be rude, @ MONTH1 to some is acceptable, but why should I be wrong comfortable in a public place, while the other is not phased. I believe that I have found a very simple compromise, which would be beneficial to me, while keeping the merchandise available. Now, most should know that there are children's sections in most, if not all, libraries. So I say this, and if we were to put all of the explicit material in its own section, that way customers looking for material now know they should go and get it. That way, I think it would reduce the discomfort of going to our public library. The benefits of this compromise seem endless to me. This way, children find themselves in a safe environment to choose their books, and adults who find it self-explanatory have a comfortable environment in which to enjoy their trip to the library. While I'm not trying to benefit those looking for the material, I think it would. That way, all the material they want can be found in one place, and they won't have to search the entire library to find it. I think I speak for the most part when I say that our public libraries should be a safe and family environment, not only for children, but for those who wish to benefit from their library experience. Thank you for your time, @ CAPS1, @ CAPS2 @ PERSON1

I'm the kind of student who likes to read a book that interests me. Most of the books I choose relate to reality, which often involves content that @ MONTH1 should be taken as explicit. I think books, magazines, movies, music, etc. should not be removed from the shelves. As citizens @ CAPS1, we have the right to freedom of expression. It gives us the freedom to say what we think and express our thoughts without restricting our personality. This law gives authors and producers the right to base their work on whatever they want. Media that @ MONTH1 is viewed as explicit is appealing to a variety of people, and to some it is viewed as disturbing. With the freedom we have as @ CAPS2, we have the choice of seeing said movies or reading said books, but we also have the choice to avoid these situations. When producers produce films containing sexual content, language or violence, they are not producing the film, expecting every citizen to see it. They know that some citizens are against this content. There is no law that obliges us to see films that we do not want to see. We have the flexibility to choose what we want and what we don't want. Explicit material is available everywhere you look. Walking through @ LOCATION2 and @ LOCATION3, we see books, music and magazines lining the walls, most of them containing explicit material. While many novels contain explicit material, there are still many that do not. People complain about explicit content in novels when in reality there are a lot of novels without explicit content. We are trained as humans to look for evil in situations. We lead pessimistic lifestyles. Citizens must learn to realize that all is not great. Seek the good in situations. There is an abundance of media that does not contain any explicit content or material of a sexual nature and we receive warnings as to what contains and does not contain this material. These warnings are mandatory! Tags such as @ CAPS3 or @ CAPS4 are set to prove that the following is open to the general public with and without parental supervision. Parents have the power to monitor what their child gets involved in. They can set rules for their children, saying that they @ MONTH1 only see movies rated @ CAPS3, or that they must have parental consent to read a magazine or novel. Parents are guardians for a reason; they have to watch and take care of their child. If they don't like music, novels, movies, etc. what is their child looking at, change it! They have the authority and the right to do so. Instead of taking explicit material off the market for everyone, limit what you, personally, want to be prohibited for your family on your own, and talk to them about it ! Katherine Paterson is absolutely right when she says, "If I have the right to take this book off the shelf." . . then you also have exactly the same right and everyone else too. And then we don't have any more books on the shelf for any of us. If we were given the right to withdraw books, films, magazines, etc. that we don't think we need to be in the market, it is likely that we would run out of media. With the billions of citizens we have in @ LOCATION1 alone, every individual is bound to find a loophole in a certain book. With every flaw found, we would like to eliminate that company book, movie, or magazine, leaving us with no variety of material to choose from. Those who are firmly committed to the removal of explicit material would act quickly on this law, rather than those who oppose it. It would create a corrupt society, with a lot of fighting. We, as human beings, enjoy the freedoms that are granted to us and the choices that we are allowed to make. Depriving ourselves of the freedom of what we read or watch would deprive us of our personality and our sense of expression. Books, movies, and magazines are meant to be read based on opinion, and it should stay that way. Books, films and magazines should be allowed to remain on the market even if they contain explicit material. The choice to read or watch this material is up to the individual and should not influence the opinions of other humans.

I don't think they should be deleted as everyone has their own opinion on what is acceptable and what is not. Just because one person doesn't like something or thinks it's offensive doesn't mean everyone is going to feel it. What one person might not like, the next person might like. The only way I think a certain material should be taken off the shelf is if there are a lot of complaints about the same material. So maybe the library should consider removing the item. That's why they have ratings and different sections in the library so that a person can know what kind of book they are going to read or what kind of movie they are going to watch. It doesn't make sense to go looking for a book or movie about something you don't like or think is offensive, there are plenty of things to choose from. How would someone feel if one of their favorite books or movies was pulled from library shelves because another person didn't like it ? They would be upset and disappointed with the situation. In conclusion, I don't agree that there are some materials that should be taken off the shelves if they are found to be offensive. Television, news, drama, life and controversy. These are just a few of the things the books are written about. Some subjects are considered vulgar and inappropriate for young audiences. Many people believe that their children have a right to learn all that books can offer, but is it really such a good thing? Books have long been an important tool for students. However, not all books should be considered appropriate for all audiences. Stories about knights and princesses are great for young people, but other stories about the darker sides of life are normally kept out of the hands of children. Books are censored for all kinds of reasons. Some of these reasons are trivial and shouldn't prevent a book from reaching its full potential. The truth is, there is a line that must not be crossed, and some books cross that line and are banned. Great. However, some books do not "cross the line" and are still banned. Honestly, you have to think carefully before you make the decision to ban a book or leave it on the shelves. If a book is written with only minor obscenities by a recognized author and it is banned, the author is under no serious pressure because the ban will be well known and consumers will always buy the book just for the chance of it. read. However, if a relatively unknown author writes a neat article that contains a few places where author @ MONTH1 has made a somewhat vulgar reference and the book is banned, the author is in serious trouble. This author can no longer afford the luxury of having his book in the library so that his work @ MONTH1 is recognized. Banning books everywhere prevents authors from making a name for themselves. Particularly vulgar books must absolutely be banned. No child should read a book intended for a purely adult audience. Children should be protected from this type of material, and the Book Ban provides this service. If a child has a strong desire to read a book, he can simply ask his parents to buy it for him, assuming the parents agree that dirty books should be read by children. If a book can provide a good discussion in a classroom and it is mostly "clean" then it should definitely be available to everyone. Just because a book contains a few areas where inappropriate references are made does not mean that students should not be able to read the book. If the learning material offered by a book “outweighs” the negative effects that the @ MONTH1 book has on a student, then the book must be available for the students to read. However, because one cannot effectively compare knowledge and harmful effects, this is a difficult statement to make. Honestly, it's too hard to say if the little issues in a book should be considered vulgar enough to ban a book. Many books should not be as available as others, but it would be too difficult to use a new system to find the books to limit, and it would make more sense to keep the current one than any other alternative. Ultimately, a system that caters to the most sheltered parents is best.

Of the history. So when someone picks up a book and finds harmful or inappropriate words or phrases in it, they instantly get the wrong idea of the book. So why shouldn't we have the same rights? If we do not agree with some of the literature that is placed in the schools, stores and homes of our society. Then we can write a novel, journal article, or even create a website on your topic. You can do a lot more web surveys. This is a more indirect approach to removing a piece of literature. If you want to have a better chance of having that book or novel taken off the shelves, you can use a poll or get people to vote, to get the opinions of others, and use them in your argument. If you have more than one opinion on a topic, you @ MONTH1 are more likely to win your argument. And it will cause much less chaos and attention to yourself and to others around you. Another reason I don't think people should be able to pick and choose what's on library shelves everywhere. I don't think anyone from anywhere should be able to walk into a library and take a piece of literature off the shelves forever. Because in today's society we have researchers working all the time, and we have so many people working on different theories and laws. These scientists @ MONTH1 need this document to test a theory, and if this document is kicked off the shelves then we could be missing out on a wide variety of important information that might help someone in the future. So the more information we remove from the shelves, the less information we will have in the future to help us solve our problems. In libraries and bookstores around the world, books are written and published on topics ranging from strange or inappropriate, to serious or violent. These books are written to target the reader's emotions that spark excitement and humor, horror and empathy among many. However, although these books are designed for a specific purpose, it is sometimes difficult to know how the book is suitable for the eyes of a young reader, or even an adult reader. These books seem unattractive and offensive. However, if they are not of interest to you as a reader, how could this book be censored without everyone's unanimous disapproval? Censorship of these books is unfair because of the right to freedom of speech and of the press, because all subjects deserve to be written, and above all because target audiences deserve books written for their benefit regardless of their location. approval. The number one reason why there should be no censorship of novels and literary works is that writers deserve freedom of speech and of the press. They voice their own opinions out loud and write about the topic that interests them most. Although they have often used highly provocative or inappropriate subjects, they still have the capacity and legal capacity to write whatever they wish. Preventing them from writing their own stubborn stories is similar to censoring books in the Nazi @ LOCATION1. Millions of books have been burned and hundreds, if not thousands, of writers have been executed for expressing in their work opinions contrary to the ideas of their government. Even though there are books out there that aren't written for all ages, they still deserve a read. The next reason books shouldn't be censored is that new ideas cover topics that were never discussed. Books and stories are meant to push the mark of what has been written and what can be written. The variety of literature is the reason it is so popular. For thousands of years, the written text has been a means of understanding and connecting with cultures and people through written language. And while @ MONTH1 stories might not be written in a way that would suit a child, that doesn't mean the story shouldn't be written or read. Its use should simply be monitored so that only those who are able to accept or understand its message are able to read it. Finally, censorship is just plain unfair because without it there is a better chance to discuss and attempt to portray stories that target a vast crowd of people. While the materials found in an @ MONTH1 story are horrible to a parent, it is @ MONTH1 a favorite form of literature for a different group of people. And limiting the literary subjects that people prefer might be paralleled with limiting a person's voice. It is simply not reasonable to allow only one category of work, with only a few varieties of messages, for a small group of people. Variety is what separates one person's opinions and makes their being different from that of another. Therefore, literature censorship should not be applied. Writing topics should be open to everyone, because whether they are offensive or not, they convey a purpose. And because writers have the right to literally illustrate what they say, there should never be a limit to these rights. This is why censorship should never be able to remove a piece of literature from a shelf.

The seven books that make up @ PERSON1's '@ CAPS1 @ CAPS2' series are frequently censored books in school libraries across the country. The main reasoning behind this is that since these books portray witchcraft in a positive light, they must harm our innocent children. Many books, from @ PERSON2 'The @ CAPS3 in the @ CAPS4' to the series '@ CAPS1 @ CAPS2' have been banned from school libraries due to their content deemed inappropriate by a group of people who fail to take the broader sense of these works into account. Works intended to be accessible to the public should not be removed from library shelves if they are found to be offensive. Under the @ ORGANIZATION1 at the @ CAPS7, every citizen has the freedom of expression, of the press and of religion. By censoring the authors' speech, their rights have been violated. The author has the right to say what he thinks should be said, and it should not be for a parent council or board of directors to forbid this right. By prohibiting the reading of books such as " @ CAPS1 @ CAPS2 " or " The @ CAPS3 in the @ CAPS4 " ; the greater significance of these works is ignored. Many conservative groups @ CAPS12 have advocated that '@ CAPS1 @ CAPS2' be banned in schools because of its portrayal of witchcraft (and therefore Satanism) and the nominal fact that @ PERSON3 has stated that @ PERSON4 (the @ CAPS15 in the series) is homosexual. However, the ultimate message of the series is that love triumphs over evil. Apparently, this is not a message worth teaching the young people of @ LOCATION1. However, even though every school in the country has removed “ @ CAPS1 @ CAPS2 ” from the shelves ; it would not and should not prevent children from reading these books. Ever since “ The @ CAPS3 in @ CAPS4 ” began to be a part of the curriculum of many schools in @ DATE1, it has been at the top of the list of most censored books due to its vulgar language and a chapter involving a prostitute. That hasn't stopped millions of teenagers from reading this novel, considered a rite of passage for most young adults. Being one of the most contested books of the past fifty years only seems to add to its appeal and popularity among the very people these censorship boards are trying to " protect ." If a parent, however, does not want their child to read such a novel; it should be left to the parent to censor what their child reads. But just because a parent doesn't want their child to read '@ CAPS1 @ CAPS2' doesn't mean every child should be denied the opportunity to read it. Censorship should be in the private and non-public sphere. Books and other materials should not be censored in libraries. In doing so ; an author's freedom of expression is violated and the broader meaning of the work is ignored. And while some @ MONTH1 groups advocate protecting the children of @ LOCATION1 from such offensive work; children will always find a way to access it

Censorship in Libraries I believe there should be censorship in libraries. In @ DATE1's society there are a lot of children who are in pain and getting into bad things. There are things kids just shouldn't see. Censorship should be used in libraries to point children in the right direction, to relieve parent stress, and because some offensive films are in fact offensive. Censorship in libraries can point children in the right direction. Chances are, if a child sees their model on the front of a movie case smoking a cigarette, then that child will likely become curious about smoking. it already happened to me. I once saw this kid that I loved drinking, and I almost started drinking myself, but because I had the right peers, I didn't. The point is, when kids see someone they enjoy doing a certain thing, it has a big impact. If this film case is detected, this kid will never even think about smoking because of his model. All parents are worried that their child will get in trouble with the law, right ? Some of the movies a child can watch in a library have actors doing illegal things. A kid will see this and then he'll probably think it's cool and go out and do the same. I've seen a lot of movies that made me want to go out and do what they did in the movie. What if that thing they see in a movie was murder? It might be crazy to think that a kid would go out and murder someone because he saw people do it in a movie, but it could happen. A few years ago, I remember reading an article in the newspaper about a child shooting his father in the head. This kid was only six years old, but he thought it was safe to play with guns because he had seen them do it in the movies. Censorship can relieve stress for some parents. Parents insist all the time on where their children are, what they are doing, who they are with, etc. If the library censors some of the music and movies kids watch, his parents won't have to worry too much about him going away and doing bad things because he sees his peers doing it. It makes parents feel good and confident in their child's life. Finally, offensive films are in fact offensive, whether to the child themselves, the parents or the target audience of the film. Keeping offensive movies censored can relieve a lot of hatred in a child's life. I say this from experience. In the movies we always see smart kids being bullied and it seems like the athletes are getting all the attention. Well, I'm kind of considered that smart kid. I feel like because of some of the movies my peers have watched, they find it okay to pick on me. It creates hatred in their hearts, all because censorship has not been used. In conclusion, it must be obvious that I think censorship should be used in libraries. Censorship should be used in libraries to point children in the right direction, to relieve parent stress, and because some offensive films are in fact offensive. With censorship, all of these things can be accomplished. It is not only useful for children, but also for parents. In my experience, censorship is a good thing to have.

There are many books, music, movies, and magazines that people find offensive. Some people even believe that these things should be taken off the shelves. I don't believe that books, music, movies, or magazines should be taken off the shelves altogether. Not everyone finds these things offensive, and they shouldn't be taken off the shelves because a few people disagree with them. First, people have different views on what they find offensive. Not everyone will find the same things offensive or want the same books or songs deleted. With people always having different views, it's hard to pull books, music, movies, or magazines off the shelves for everyone. Just because one person doesn't agree with what is said in the movie or book doesn't mean everyone wants that movie or book deleted. If someone found my favorite book offensive, I wouldn't want it taken off the shelves altogether. Equally important, if every book, song, movie, and magazine someone finds offensive were taken off the shelves, there wouldn't be many books, movies, songs, or magazines left. Author Katherine Paterson once said, " But if I have the right to take a book off the shelf - this job that I hate - then you have the exact same right and everyone else too." And then we don't have any more books on the shelf for any of us. @ CAPS1 says if every book that offends someone was taken off the shelves there would be no books to read. People find different things offensive and if everyone took these things off the shelves, no one would be left with them. Finally, if someone finds a book offensive, they don't have to read it. When someone finds an offensive book, movie, song, or magazine, they don't need to look at it or read it. Instead of removing it from the shelves, the person just couldn't read it. Not everyone finds the same books offensive and removing them from the shelves could upset a lot of people. When someone finds something offensive, they may just avoid it instead of having it removed and bothering others. If someone was offended by one of my favorite books, I would rather avoid reading it than taking it off the shelves so I couldn't read it. Some people find many books, songs, movies, and magazines offensive. They would like these things to be taken off the shelves permanently. However, I don't believe these things should be deleted. Taking them off the shelves might make some people happy, it might also upset even more. Not everyone finds the same things offensive and shouldn't be taken off the shelves because a few people disagree with them
Imagine walking out of your house and seeing a giant bonfire at the end of the street, in the open air. You see men walk into a library empty-handed and come out with armfuls of books, magazines, movies, and other media. The men then throw them into the raging hell and you seem to have cremated them, lost forever. This is what will happen if we allow our libraries to be censored. We should not let the censorship of our libraries take place as it violates a constitutional right, will gradually make our society more and more ignorant and let this nation move from a democratic nation to a nation where the beliefs and ideals of the people are controlled by a small group of people. Allowing the censorship of our libraries to take place will violate a basic, clear and simple constitutional right. In @ ORGANIZATION1 it is clearly stated that there will be freedom of the press. By discarding certain literary works, this right will be rejected and by violating a constitutional right, what will happen next ? Will our freedom of expression be denied, or our freedom to assemble? As citizens of @ LOCATION1, we cannot let this happen to our great nation. By allowing certain books and essays to be thrown out of our libraries, people's knowledge base will eventually shrink considerably. Take for example the theory of evolution of @ PERSON1, a very sensitive subject among people of faith @ CAPS1. If all of his work on this matter was rejected, a lot of very valuable information for biologists would be lost and these biologists would not be able to improve the existing pool of information. If this were to happen, our civilization would experience a decrease in intellect and increasing ignorance regarding many areas of knowledge. Imagine @ CAPS2 in the @ DATE1. Hitler's @ ORGANIZATION2 has seized power and we systematically destroy any documents they find subversive to the @ ORGANIZATION2 cause, only allowing documents containing beliefs and ideals they believed to be correct. exist in libraries. This is exactly what we would do if we allowed censorship of our libraries. Censorship of libraries would be controlled by a relatively small group of people, which means that the censorship would be controlled by the beliefs and ideals of those same people, and those same beliefs and ideals would thus be imposed on the people, shaping the beliefs and ideals. ideals of the masses to these privileged few. In conclusion, allowing censorship to operate in our public libraries will dismantle the basic structure of our society by violating a constitutional right, gradually making our society more and more ignorant, and leaving behind the beliefs and ideals of our people. rest in the hands of a select few. This is not what our @ CAPS3 @ CAPS4 was planning to become @ LOCATION2 and they were right. Allowing censorship to exist in our public libraries is just plain wrong

I believe the current way of censoring and removing material works and should continue. While not everyone @ MONTH1 likes a particular novel or book, libraries cannot remove all the books that a person dislikes, as Katherine Paterson said. When a book seems so controversial that the majority of people disapprove of it, then the book is usually taken off the shelves. The possibility of children seeing the offensive material seems unlikely. Most public libraries do not place offensive material near children's books. In my local library, there is a section that groups the most offensive or obscene books in one place. To acquire these books, you must have permission from your parents or be NUM1 years old. It is very unlikely that a child will ever see the documents in question. Many people who find the material offensive should also remember the time and place the story originated. @ PERSON3 @ PERSON2 @ MONTH1 contains racial slurs, but considering the time and place of the novel, these slurs were normal for the time. Someone can't be frustrated with a novel written @ NUM2 years ago because it contains something offensive by today's standards. While I believe that, for the most part, libraries shouldn't censor or delete documents, some restrictions should be in place to prevent libraries from extremely dangerous documents. For example, libraries should not have dirty magazines or films on their shelves. If a large majority of people want to ban a particular material, then it is difficult to ignore them. When a book is so vulgar that people start to protest the book, there are questions as to whether the book should stay on the library shelves. When a high percentage of people join this cause, then it should be banned. Censorship or deletion of material from libraries remains a hot topic today. I believe the current system in place for censoring or deleting books is doing its job, and should continue. So few people disapprove of a particular material, the book stays in most shelves uncensored. When a lot of people start to protest against this same material, it has a high probability of being banned. With this process, every book that contains a racial insult or questionable scene is not deleted, while those that really deserve it are deleted.

As far back as people can remember, books have been banned for various reasons. Whether it is a time of war or a religious restriction, it is always seen as a negative thing and therefore should not be any different today. Although @ MONTH1 is a little less extreme, books or content such as movies, music, or magazines should not be removed from library shelves based on someone else's opinion. It is a right to be able to obtain the information offered by these media. No document should ever be removed from a public library on the basis of censorship. Some @ MONTH1 argue that some @ MONTH1 material is offensive to other groups of people, but who is it to judge how another is feeling. The material is written or made to show the feelings of the author and how he wants his feelings or knowledge to be represented. The author is simply taking advantage of their freedom of expression. It is the public's responsibility to know how they use the information they receive. It's still a piece of history and was recorded for a reason. Religion is always a hot spot when it comes to censorship, but isn't it in our constitution. Freedom of religion includes the way we interpret and study our religions. Most have holy books and writings. Many express their religion through music and culture. The public has the right to access this material. There are rare situations where the @ MONTH1 restrictions must be observed but simply based on age. Censorship is a disgrace and should not be enforced in libraries. People have different criteria when it comes to deciding on an offense level. For the most part, if a 50 year old @ CAPS1 woman read a violent book with profanity and sexual content, she might think it was offensive. Likewise, if a carefree man of twenty-one read the exact same book, he would probably appreciate its contents. This difference of opinion poses a huge problem in allowing libraries to censor their selection. I think it would be unfair to remove books that certain audiences would appreciate. Instead of completely banning certain texts, why not move them to another section of the library? Libraries might take some time to separate books into categories, and books they find offensive might be placed in a separate section of the library. This section could be as simple as a separate shelf, or could go to the end of a separate room or area closed with a curtain. Either way, getting rid of books altogether because of their content is a terrible idea. Authors could potentially lose money as a result of the censorship action. They put in many hours and a lot of effort writing books and novels. Some spend years trying to perfect their masterpieces. Magazines and movies offer the same time, but they also bring in an unimaginable amount of money. If these writers, directors and producers see their specific product taken off the shelves, it would offend them. They might have a decrease in sales which would also lead to a decrease in money. The idea is simply unfair. Librarians have the right to post whatever content they choose, but having them remove products they think are correct is ridiculous. I think censorship is a terrible idea. If anything were to be banned from a library, it should be the censorship itself!

There are many reasons why parents all over the world want to hide these things from the eyes of young people, such as; personal influence, emotional growth and even the risk of a child becoming disobedient to the parent. These are all valid reasons why certain things should be removed from public view. These are all things that parents want to keep away from their children in order to keep them safe. People are very easily moved by any form of information, song or story. Children are easily affected by behavior, maybe they just saw a movie by @ CAPS1 @ CAPS2 and thought he was so cool and wanted to be like him. If a child is exposed to a movie of great violence or bad influence, then the child @ MONTH1 begins to follow what is happening there and begins not to listen to their parents. It is right to keep these bad influences away until they are able to deal with such violent or unhappy things. So yes, some materials should be removed from public view, for the safety of the community and its children. This book which is offensive to someone is not intended for him; the opinion of the authors should not matter. Second, everyone's opinion is different. One person @ MONTH1 finds the book offensive and the next person @ MONTH1 does not. Other people @ MONTH1 haven't even read the offending book. But no matter if the book is read or not, it should not be taken off the shelf; it's just not fair to all the other people who actually want to read this book. Don't go where other people can't read the book if they like these kinds of themes. You wouldn't want that to happen to you. No one would like that. Just pick a book that has a theme you like. So as you can see I don't think it's fair for books to be taken off the shelves if people find the book offensive. Some people @ MONTH1 like this theme of the book or the story in it. Some people have different opinions about the book, or it means something different to them. And just because someone finds a book offensive doesn't mean it should be taken off the shelf; it's just not fair to other people.

Libraries are a place where anyone can find books to read, on any subject they choose. It is a right which must remain in the hands of the reader and not of the library. Anyone can read whatever they like, and people working in libraries should not have any influence on the books people read. Censorship of books is totally unnecessary. If someone wants to read on a specific topic, then they have the right to do so. Reading a book that is offensive to the reader is the reader's choice; no one forced them to read it. When he finds an offensive book, the reader can then make that decision and not read the book. However, just because this reader finds this book offensive does not mean that another person would, and that other person has the right to read this book if they wish. Finding an offensive book is just opinion and has no factual evidence. So who has the right to say whether a book is offensive or not? Just because someone who runs a library thinks a book is offensive or inappropriate doesn't mean it should be taken off the shelves. There is no one who can tell whether a book is offensive or not. Other things like music, movies or magazines should also not be censored, although some already are. Movies, for example, are all rated, thus giving the viewer a choice of what level of movie they want to watch. Viewers should not expect to watch a movie rated “ @ CAPS1 ” and not see any content containing foul language, violence or other “ offensive ” material. By choosing a higher rated film, the viewer makes their own choice of what to see, and therefore librarians should not take it upon themselves to remove these films. It is simply not their responsibility. The music is also rated and, if necessary, bears a parental warning label, telling the listener that this album has explicit content. Although just like with movies or books, everyone has the right to listen to the music they want and shouldn't have to look anywhere other than a library because the librarian thought the music was inappropriate. Magazines @ MONTH1 should not be rated, but that does not mean that the library should make the executive decision to rate them and get rid of those deemed “ offensive ”. As mentioned several times above, it is the reader's choice to view the material; not that of the librarian. Whether it is books, music, films or magazines, the consumer has the right to read, listen or see what he wants, free from the influence of librarians. Each person has a say in the material they choose to consume, and no one else has the right to tell them otherwise.

It would offend the person who wrote the book or made the movie. There are many reasons why censorship shouldn't be in libraries. My first reason is freedom of expression. People have the right to say or write what they believe. Just because it might offend someone doesn't mean you should take the opportunity to read away from people they don't offend. Give people the right to read and write whatever they want. Also, if you use censorship, it will negatively affect the literature. By using censorship, you will have to remove the books that offend people from the shelves. Not having these books on the shelves means that no one can read them. If no one can read the books, no one learns. Another thing to consider is the authors' money. Often at the library, if I see a book that I really like, I'll buy it. But removing those books from the shelves means no one will see them. Authors write these books so that they can get their point across and earn money. If we do away with the books, they don't make money and they don't get their point across. In conclusion, I think censorship is a bad idea overall. One because of freedom of speech. Second, it could have a drastic effect on the literature. Third, it takes away money and perspective from authors. These are the important reasons why I do not overdo the censorship.
