Should any material deemed offensive be removed from our library shelves ? Many people find the materials they see in libraries, such as books, movies, music, magazines, etc., offensive ; but does that mean they should be deleted? I, along with many others, believe that libraries should not censor offensive material. Censing libraries would neglect parental responsibilities, destroy our profitable media and be unconstitutional. Parents are responsible for their children, not only when it comes to providing food and shelter, but also when their children view inappropriate or offensive material. If you don't want your child to be offended or see vulgar shows, lyrics, and music, don't let them see it. For example, if a child listens to a sex song on their I-pod, take it off. It is not a right to have the device, it is a privilege and the parents are out loud to withdraw privileges. In addition to neglecting the responsibilities of parents, it would be a big blow to the media economically. Most media are viewed because of inappropriate material appearing in their shows, books and music. If you censor all of this material, fewer movie tickets will be bought, fewer books will be sold, and less music will be listened to. In a time of recession, like the one we are emerging from now, it is more beneficial to provide as much income as possible, instead of destroying current opportunities for profit. Both of these points are valid, but more importantly, censoring libraries would be unconstitutional. In the preamble, we have the right to freedom of expression and of the press. Such offensive content is included in this right. I understand that additions can be made to specify what type of speech and press is appropriate, but how will officers monitor this. Not to mention all the jail space that would be needed for people smuggling inappropriate material to buyers. In short, censoring libraries is a bad idea in the areas of parenting, media economics, and our constitutional rights. By negatively affecting all of these areas, the consequences are much more influential than the benefits. Obviously, censorship is not the answer to offensive material

In today's literary world, it is never difficult to find a subject that interests you. Sci-fi, thriller, romance, how to build a car from household materials and more are all waiting for you at your nearest bookstore or library. With this vast array of topics, it's no surprise that you find authors who have decided to go against societal norms and write a book that is controversial in the ideas it presents. These books will often be placed on a “burn list” or censorship list and be removed from the shelves of local libraries in order to protect the clients of those institutions from the ideas of these books. Many have argued that this is a way to keep society pure, but this censorship of literary works is possibly one of the biggest mistakes a civilization can make. Removing books from library shelves is a form of censorship, a flagrant violation of @ CAPS1. In @ LOCATION1, everyone has certain inalienable rights. These were written in our @ CAPS1 as the first ten additions to @ CAPS1. One of these rights is freedom of expression, or the right to express one's opinion. By removing a book from the shelf of a library, you silence the author of that book and thus take away the author's freedom of expression. This clearly violates @ CAPS1 and is therefore unconstitutional and illegal in @ LOCATION1. By violating @ CAPS1 openly, it opens the door to other domains to violate in @ CAPS1. The president is now a dictator, we are now a communist country, and many other actions are allowed, leaving @ CAPS1 like a meaningless piece of paper. Without the @ CAPS1, the @ LOCATION1 is like any other country and has no leadership. This leads to a downward spiral of our society. Silencing the voice of authors also prevents new ideas from entering a society. Each year, thousands of new books are presented to the public at @ CAPS8. Many of them have new ideas that help shape our society for the future. If you get these books off the shelves and out of the hands of the public, you effectively stop any change in new ideas in a company. Nothing would ever improve and society would remain at the same level as when the censorship began. Censorship can also lead to the downfall of a company. In @ PERSON1's novel '@ CAPS9 @ NUM1' the censorship of books has gone so far that all great literary works in the world are banned. Anyone caught reading a thought-provoking book locked up or killed. The main characters' job as a firefighter is not to put out fires, but to set fire to books that encourage people to think. The censorship of this company had gone so far that no one did anything, they just sat at home and watched TV all day. A lot of people will argue that pornography is something that should be censored outside of society, but the problem is, once you start censoring where do you stop? Censorship of pornography would lead to censorship of romance novels, which would lead to censorship of magic books, and so on until you censor @ CAPS10 @ CAPS11 or @ CAPS12. By censoring thought-provoking books and movies, you quickly lose interest in higher education. This is why censorship can quickly lead to the collapse of a society. While @ MONTH1 censorship seems like a good idea, it really is one of the biggest mistakes a company can make. This can lead to silencing all voices of change in a society, forcing the society to stop and stay on the right track. Libraries and schools are meant to be places that encourage free thinking, discovery and learning. Censorship prevents these things from happening. Because @ CAPS11 or she does not agree with the opinions expressed? The grounds for censorship are not legitimate either. Most justifications for censorship would not stand the test of time. Many of the books that were contested in the past are now considered classics and / or important works, such as To @ CAPS1 a @ CAPS2, @ ORGANIZATION1, The @ CAPS3 of @ ORGANIZATION2 and @ CAPS4 @ CAPS5 @ PERSON3. Additionally, To @ CAPS1 a @ CAPS9 is about a lawyer defending a black man falsely accused at @ LOCATION1. The main antagonist is an ignorant and racist man. The book itself isn't racist, just the villain of the story. Censorship for such reasons is different from not allowing a young child to watch something violent. Preventing a child from seeing a movie rated @ CAPS10 or reading a letter to @ ORGANIZATION3 is a separate matter from censorship. I define censorship as preventing someone from seeing or reading something because of personal opinions rather than for the good of the protected person. Keep children safe when they are young, if necessary, but as they grow and mature it is essential that they are also allowed to mature in their reading. If someone lives their life reading only the books that others choose for them and seeing only the movies and shows chosen for them, then @ CAPS11 or she won't be their own person. They will not have their own opinions and will be largely ignorant of the world around them. @ PERSON2 said: '@ CAPS11 who destroys a good book, kills reason itself.' @ CAPS12 is what happens to people who grew up in censorship ; they have very little reason. Many of these people understand others better, promoting tolerance. Censorship takes all of these wonderful qualities away from people. Anyone can own them. Censorship cannot be taken as the norm. Whether or not you should read a certain book is up to you. The guidelines for films follow the same pattern. Your parents helped you choose suitable films when you were young. As you grow up you learn to read movies and watch the ratings. If it seems intimidating, or inappropriate, or violent, you choose whether or not to see it. They should be removed because offensive things can lead to more dramatic things. It's almost like when people were separated by race. Segregation led to fights between people. How would you feel if the segregation was still there? You might be upset and find it unfair because there are certain things that you can't do. This is probably what some people feel when they are offended by the media. Why shouldn't they be removed for offending a few people ? They should not be deleted as they could help the younger generations decide what is right and wrong. They could help by giving people a choice of what is good and what is not. If there was nothing that could offend anyone, how would the younger generations learn to decide what is right or wrong? In my opinion, it all depends on how many people are offended by it. There are ups and downs in all cases. If you took out everything that offended someone, it would be more difficult to teach the younger generations to decide for themselves what is right and wrong. This would mainly be because you would only have one point of view, the point of view that is perfect for everyone. In my opinion, this point of view does not exist. Therefore, I believe that by removing anything that is offensive to anyone, we would not have media. However, if we did not remove anything offensive, serious problems could arise. For example, fights could break out or wars could even start, depending on the number of people offended. The last thing we need in our society is to fight. So my answer for removing offensive material should be yes and no.

People learn from books; books with happy endings, sad endings, and horrible endings are all capable of providing lessons to the reader. Many say history repeats itself. That is why history is taught in schools so that bad events that have occurred in history can be avoided. The same goes for the books that are on the shelves in the library. By reading a book, the reader is able to experience the life of the characters as if they were living with the characters. Through the experiences of the characters, the reader can observe all the things wrong and well done by this character without actually experiencing the experience. By the end of the book, the reader will have known their perspective on life and will try not to make the same mistakes as the characters in the book. Libraries are a place for everyone; from young children to the elderly, so there is material for all ages. When you go to a library you assume that whatever type of book you want to read, they will have it. From personal preferences to school research projects, should libraries have it all? Well, some libraries want to take that concept out. A library has books on almost any subject. This is because of the individual differences of the people who go to the library. Someone from an extremist religious group might go there to read something about their religion. If a strict @ CAPS1 could find a book on extreme religion, he might be offended. However, this situation could go both ways. Due to the individuality of people and the different beliefs and customs, we will all appreciate and belittle all types of literature. Most libraries are large enough to be sorted into sections. There are sections for Young Adults, Mature Adults, Kids, Non-Fiction, Fiction, Sci-Fi, etc. If a child ventures into the mature adult section and flips through the pages of a book that is above their maturity level, then it is the child's fault. Mature people who can handle the content of more adult-oriented books should not be punished by the library for removing all books of that content because a child did not stay in the designated area. Along with different cultural beliefs come different beliefs and views on everyday things. Some readers might strongly disagree with a book, and others might recommend it to all of their friends and family. A book to one person can mean something totally different to another. It might be understandable if there were books on sex, for example, right next to children's books, but that is not the case in most libraries. Libraries might even have a restricted section that alerts readers to the content of books in that specific area. Books in libraries are written for many types of people. Age, gender, religion, maturity, race, political beliefs, etc. will all affect the way you approach a book. Whether or not you are interested in a book depends on your beliefs, values or customs. That being said, why would a library remove books that only a certain percentage of people would disagree with ? Carrying out books on a certain subject might confuse people who like that type of book or it might even relate to their daily life. A library is a place of knowledge. It is filled with facts, beliefs, theories and opinions of people. Would not depriving someone of the possibility of reading a subject revoke the author and his freedom of expression ? Just because of a controversial or mature topic shouldn't mean people shouldn't be allowed to read it. If people could only read a certain literature that someone else decides whether or not it is okay to read, then where is their freedom? A library is a place for everyone. Are there universally bad books that no one should read? Are the good and the bad no longer matters of opinion for the readers themselves? The answer is no. Censorship is a terrible practice that masquerades as a godsend. The right to read certain books should not be left to a few curators, because everyone has their own opinion on everything. There is always something we can potentially learn from books, and it's never fair to take it away. Freedom of speech should certainly come into play here too, allowing the words of the authors to be heard without the interference of those who would dictate what we read. There is a reason libraries have many sections. They must respond to the individual tastes of the masses, regardless of what others find offensive. If someone went through the library and burned all the books they didn't like, there would be next to nothing left. Send another person with different tastes, and then you will have a completely empty library. It is far better to leave all the books alone so that everyone can find something to read with pleasure. Basically there are bound to be people who have similar opinions to the author of just about anything, so allow the authors to share those opinions. Then we have the knowledge part of the problem. Material that is offensive to one person can be what another person wants or needs to read, whether it is for fun or for the classroom. There is much to be learned psychologically and human nature from almost any writing. Perhaps a restricted section would be appropriate if the problem involved the corruption of innocent minds, but a full censor would never be necessary. If we start to restrict this freedom, what will we be then? In short, censorship is a harmful practice that should never be used. People all have their own opinions, all media can be learned from and our freedom should not be restricted. The practice of censorship is what really should be banned from the shelves.

Censorship is one of the many important issues facing the world today. Many argue that materials deemed offensive are harmful to society and should not be tolerated. Others believe that freedom of expression is a universal right that should extend to all forms of human expression. The question is further complicated by the concept of what is and is not appropriate for children. Are there materials that are acceptable for adults, but not for children ? Questions like this have plagued mankind for hundreds of years, and there is no simple solution. Today, so many people think censorship is a bad word. In fact, there is nothing fundamentally wrong with the concept of censorship. It's only when people start to abuse their power and censor documents that shouldn't be censored that problems arise. For example, many countries have restrictions on the sale and possession of copies of "@ PERSON2", the book that @ PERSON1 wrote as a kind of mission statement for @ LOCATION1. While many of the ideas in the book are horribly offensive, it still shouldn't be censored. People have the right to read the book and make up their own minds about the teachings of @ PERSON1, it is not for the government to decide for them. While oppressive dictatorship and mass murder are crimes, reading about them is not. There is little material available that should rightly be censored and removed from the hands of adults. If someone understands what they are reading and is able to form an informed opinion about the material, then no one has the right to prevent them from expanding their knowledge or expressing themselves by creating similar material. However, the question changes completely when you consider children. If adults want to watch pornography or read stories of extreme violence, that's their business. However, these concepts are obviously inappropriate for children, and any decent parent would not want their young children to fill their heads with such things. Children should be introduced to these concepts slowly and gently so that they can fully understand them. In the case of children, careful censorship is necessary for healthy development. When it comes to libraries, there are very few materials that should be banned. If libraries are meant to be places of learning, then one has no right to limit the information they contain. However, that doesn't mean that there shouldn't be limitations. Libraries should offer a children's section, as many do, which would contain material only appropriate for young people. Then it is the parents' responsibility to make sure their child stays in this section. When a parent thinks the child is ready to explore the adult section, they are free to take their child there. This system gives parents the ability to keep their children away from harmful material, without removing it from adult hands. Many would argue that unsupervised children could gain access to inappropriate material, but this is really an issue that needs to be addressed by parents, not the library. After all, it's better for a few kids to see something they shouldn't have for all adults to read censored material. In conclusion, censorship is a concept that has its place in society, but should be used with great caution. When the goal is to protect people, especially children, from harmful substances, it can be used sparingly. However, when those in power use censorship to attack ideas with which they do not agree, it becomes a form of oppression. Above all, people must be free to educate themselves, to form their own opinions and to express themselves. If someone doesn't like a piece of gear, they can leave it alone, but they should never try to get it out of someone else's hands.

I don't think those words empower the book. The @ CAPS1 books, considered offensive, are a glimpse into history and culture. Removing these books will limit education. Books should not be censored. The popular book '@ ORGANIZATION1 @ ORGANIZATION1.' The book tells the story of a young white boy who runs away with an older black man. In history, the word "nigger" is frequently used. A lot of people were offended by the use of this word, so they republished a new version of the book, replacing “ nigger ” with “ slave ”. The folks at @ CAPS1 were happy with the word change, but others felt that by censoring the word it took away a very important part of the story. I agree with this last statement. The setting for the story was when black people were slaves and known as negroes. I agree that the word negro has a strong connotation, but that is the purpose of using the word. The author used it so that the reader can get a feel for life at the time. Thinking of the generations to come, who will not experience black slavery or oppression, the book gives a raw glimpse into the life of a black man. The word itself is a symbolism of slavery, without it the book is not as powerful. Censorship is a fine line, and everyone has a different place where they draw that line. The story of @ ORGANIZATION1 is just one example of censorship. On television, nudity and language are censored when deemed inappropriate. Books should not be removed from the shelf as they will entertain and educate other children or parents. Human beings, like snowflakes, are very much alike in a unique way. Just as no two snowflakes are the same, no two humans are exactly the same. As everyone has their differences, there are always those who have a greater sense of curiosity and prefer to think outside the box. However, it is difficult for these curious people to expand their quest for knowledge, if they have restrictions on what they can read or study. Most people would answer yes to the question because anything a person reads, watches or listens to @ MONTH1 is considered offensive or rude to someone else. Some materials in libraries should not be removed from shelves if they are deemed offensive because different people find different materials offensive, people sometimes come specifically to libraries to look for materials they cannot find elsewhere, and if a person finds material offensive, they don't need you to continue reading, watching or listening to it. The first reason why censorship should not take place in libraries is that different people find different material offensive. Everyone is different, and people have all kinds of opinions about books, movies, magazines, music, etc. In addition, several different ethnicities exist in the world, and there are many non-fiction books that educate people about different cultures around the world. Another reason why some materials should not be taken off the shelves if they are deemed offensive is that sometimes people come specifically to libraries to look for materials that they cannot find elsewhere. Libraries are the only place people go if they're looking for a certain book or maybe even a movie that they can't find in a video store. In my experience, there have been an endless number of times that I wanted to read a book that I had heard about, and I went straight to the library and found it there. Also, since there is no video store in the city where I live, I go to the library for movies because I know they have a lot to choose from. Some of the books and movies that me or others like @ MONTH1 find offensive to others, so if they were taken off the library shelves I don't know if I would go to the library that often. A third reason why censorship shouldn't take place in libraries is that people don't have to read what they @ MONTH1 find offensive. Everyone has a choice of what material they acquire from a library, unless it is something they need to read for school. If a person hears about a book that @ MONTH1 finds offensive to them, why would they read the book. Additionally, if a person accidentally consults a book or watches a movie from the library that they find offensive, they can always stop reading the book or watching the movie. Censorship shouldn't happen in libraries because everyone has different opinions. Libraries assume that if someone finds offensive material, they will simply stop reading it. Also, if libraries remove all the material that someone finds offensive, what will be left to read, watch or listen to ?

When I was in fifth grade, chaos erupted in my community. Everyone - teachers, students, parents, school board members, community leaders - had something to say on the topic at hand. This topic was censorship. Parents of a high school student were outraged that their daughter had read The @ ORGANIZATION1 @ ORGANIZATION1 in class. In the opinion of these parents, the rape scene in the book was far too disturbing for their precious daughter. While this seemed like a fair position to take, the parents then took it a step further. They sought to ban the book from schools in our township, wanting to spare all other children the experience of being exposed to @ CAPS1 was clearly traumatic material. This crusade asked the questions " @ CAPS1 can and should be censored ?" And when?'. As the debate continued, I began to meditate on the subject myself. Who had the right to tell me @ CAPS1 that I could read? Or listen? Where to watch? The answer I came up with was “ nobody ”. No one has the right to censor someone else. This comes with one exception: parents and children. Parents are responsible for looking after their children. They should use their best judgment to decide @ CAPS1 that their children are old enough and mature enough to hear, see or read. This was also true in the censorship of @ ORGANIZATION1. No one fought against the family because they didn't want their own child to read the novel; It wasn't until they tried to keep others out of the book that the problem arose. This is why libraries should not remove documents from their shelves because they are, in the eyes of some, offensive documents. The music you love @ MONTH1 offends me. Books that your teacher @ CAPS2 assigned to @ MONTH1 are not suitable for five year olds. Your @ MONTH1 friends will be offended by your favorite movie or @ CAPS3 show. These feelings are subjective; almost nothing is universally offensive or universally appropriate. We, as a society, need to be able to accept it. We must not hinder our children's ability to learn from the mistakes of book and movie characters, singers, comedians and artists. If we remove this ability, we are preparing these future adults to make mistakes that could have been avoided by giving them the chance to learn. Censorship in libraries is almost a primitive, if not childish way of excluding what one might think is offensive to everyone, isn't it? Think about it. A kid who doesn't let another kid play with him at recess today, just because he stuck his tongue out at him during math the night before, seems pretty childish, and several much more reasonable solutions spring to mind. of anyone who sits down and ponders the situation for more than a second. This scenario parallels censorship in libraries. A book is a book to read. This is, of course, an obvious statement. But why read a book? Receive information. To learn something you didn't know, or to build on knowledge you already had. How to cook an exquisite meal? Go read a book to find out. How to draw linear equations? There are books that will explain it to you. Is it fair for a keen astronomer, not feeling pressured to know how long a turkey should be in an oven, to remove a book that teaches this very? Now, of course, cooking a turkey probably won't be offensive to someone browsing their local library, though, just think about it. The book has been written, so isn't that a sure sign that it's not offensive to at least one person, i.e. the author? There are things people will not agree with. And just when you think you find something that everyone loves, someone will come and disturb the peace. Not everyone likes rap music, but it still plays on the radio. It is a free choice to listen to it. It is a free choice to read a book no matter what it says. Just because people are unlucky enough to be subjected to material that they find offensive, by accident or otherwise, and then project their dismissive comments to a maintainer, does not mean that offensive material should be discarded. Perhaps radios and libraries can be looked at still further. The radios have specific channels, playing specific music. There is a country music channel for those who want to listen to country music. As for libraries, there is of course the @ ORGANIZATION1, but that's about all that is categorized. Suppose books are even more distinguished by their placement in a bookcase. A certain designated area for certain genres. That way, if you happen to find any nasty @ CAPS1 concentration camp books, you can avoid @ CAPS2 and @ CAPS1 from the @ CAPS4 @ CAPS5 @ CAPS6 @ CAPS7 section in your library. Problem @ CAPS8. I find it hard to see something so offensive if I can't even literally see it. You see, outright deletion isn't really the best option to please dissatisfied people. The compromise is. Now, after pondering this situation for over a second, I'm sure you've thought of much more reasonable solutions than something as ridiculous as censorship. Now the best part is seeing people enjoy books and not be offended by the ones they don't like anymore.

Views on censorship in libraries certainly vary from person to person. There are those who are offended by the material available to everyone, and then there are those who want the right to read, listen and watch what they want. I believe there are pros and cons to each choice, anyway, but there has to be some sort of censorship in libraries; the line must be drawn somewhere. The words of the music can be extremely offensive to some people. Inappropriate scenes in movies, whether it's two people of the opposite sex or moments of intense action, are not things young people should be exposed to. Easy access to the library is part of the problem. Anyone of any age can get their hands on just about anything they want. From my own experience, I have had the opportunity to get anything I wanted from the library. The advertising images on the covers of books, movies, magazines, etc. gave me the wrong idea of what the material actually contained when I was younger. I came home from a day at the library with material my parents didn't approve of. If you look at it from another point of view, you would probably think that if we got rid of all the material that someone found offensive, our libraries would end up with next to nothing. In fact, I believe that once people realized that exposure to this kind of material is offensive, writers would change the way they write; directors would change the way they produced films; the artists changed the lyrics of their songs. So yes, the library shelves would have been stripped of a lot of materials, but they would be replaced with what people want. Others might claim that they have the right to read, listen and watch what they want. This @ MONTH1 is true, but shouldn't other people be allowed to let their children go to libraries without worrying about the horrible material they might be exposed to? Although for some people this @ MONTH1 argument goes both ways, if the line is never drawn on what is available, who knows what the @ MONTH1 world is coming from. From there, the material can only become more offensive, more disturbing, and leave a bigger effect on people's minds. Children will be exposed to the “evils” of this world even at a younger age, and if that is all they ever know, they will not realize what else this world has to offer them. Writers, directors, producers, and artists will all change their material if we show them that's not what we want.

If a book uses vulgar and inappropriate language, it should be censored in some way. With that in mind, I shouldn't be able to pick a book and open it to find sexual dialogue. If I walk around my local library and see just a magazine with a nude photo on the front, I'm going to wonder about my library's censorship policy. Another example would be if I take a book and start browsing it and it has an inappropriate image, I'm going to question my library's censorship policy. Likewise, if a magazine has an extremely violent or extremely gory image, it should be darned. Overall, if a book or magazine is grossly inappropriate, it should somehow be censored. A lot of people think that libraries should be censored in some way or another to keep certain types of books away from people. How does this really help? Even if you delete certain books or music from a library, that doesn't mean people still won't get the same information from elsewhere. Besides a lot of things that people should be censored, it's probably not that bad. I think it is better for someone to read something that happens to them and then experience it. As Katherine Paterson said, if we let people get rid of the music books that they think are bad for people to read or listen to, we'll be left with that. Nothing! Across the board people think library censorship is for the greater good, it just has too many bad sides to have a good effect. When people try to censor things, they normally take them off the shelves and throw them away. But, in today's tech world, that doesn't stop people from achieving their goal. We have the Internet which allows people to download books and music to share. So yes, many of you cannot get a book from the library but you can almost always find it online. As a result, trying to censor libraries by removing books and music is really doing nonsense. How do you determine what should be censored? People all have different ideas of what is good for the public and what is not. A deleted book could insult a group of people because it relates in some way to them. Then you lose business and drive people crazy at the same time. In a way, isn't it better for people to learn bad things like crime and death in ways that aren't real and don't hurt. When things like that happen in a book, they don't normally end there. They show the results or how the situation was handled. Which could come to the aid of people who would find themselves in the same kind of situation later in their life. Which makes it very difficult to determine what should and shouldn't be censored. Katherrine Paterson has even said that if we let people censor what they think is wrong there will be nothing left. Everything will be gone, because every person in the world would find something and every book they could find bad. Even though there is a book that people agree should be censored, there are people who think otherwise. No books would be left if we censored libraries because people might find bad or immoral things in every book. Overall, library censorship ends up being more painful than it is worth. It does not prevent people from getting the information in any other way. There is no way to decide what should be censored. And, censoring things will cause people to want other things censored, which leaves nothing. In conclusion, censorship doesn't really stop people and ends up causing bigger problems.

Her quote means that there might be a book, magazine, etc., on a shelf that someone shouldn't be seeing. I believe that some materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should not be taken off the shelves if they are found to be offensive. There are ways to avoid seeing them. You can walk away if you notice anything that you find offensive or if you stay away from that area of the library. There will be a lot of things that people find offensive and inappropriate, but there's not much you can do about it. The best thing to do is ignore it and go. Conflicting works of art such as books, music, and movies have always been seen in libraries. Whether it's @ CAPS1 or @ CAPS2 @ CAPS3 @ NUM1, someone is going to be offended. But whether or not these offending works should be banned is a common topic among writers, musicians and moviegoers. Personally, I believe that all these works have the right to be seen, heard or read, because the creator has made a lot of efforts to express his opinion and has the right to freedom of the press. You could take any famous job and someone might be offended @ CAPS5 for posting something contrary to their beliefs. But that doesn't mean that this work should be banned! To ban a book would mean a total rejection of the thoughts and opinions of the author, and everyone has a right to it. Censorship of any work is unconstitutional because as citizens of @ LOCATION1 we have total freedom of the press. You just can't enforce censorship because whether or not you keep it on the shelves people are going to be offended. Moreover, as @ PERSON1 @ CAPS4 @ NUM2 shows, censorship of books could lead to a society unable to have any real knowledge of the past and the feelings and thoughts of people of this age. For me, “ offensive ” books, movies and music are not bad, they are just a stimulus for debate. They can allow you, rather than the sole author, to express your feelings about what has been presented in the works. But to completely remove competition from the debate would be sabotage. @ PERSON2 @ LOCATION1 that 'if I have the right to take this book off the shelf ... then you also have the exact same right and everyone else too.' @ CAPS5 saying this, she expresses that if we could all go to a library and remove the books, magazines, movies or music that we don't like, then there would be absolutely nothing left. Each job would be deleted because at least one person is offended @ CAPS5 for each such job. Therefore, to allow books to be read, to listen to music and to watch movies is to give everyone the freedom to write down their thoughts or positions. Censorship of any work, anywhere, makes it possible to "silence" ideas. These ideas are the ones that move the company @ CAPS5 forward, making us think and helping us to formulate our opinions. @ CAPS5 enabling this, we are creating future generations of great thinkers. In this case, @ CAPS5 keeping books, magazines and music on the shelves, we can continue to " learn from the past " and use the information and ideas that have been used throughout history.

If someone is offended by a book or movie in a library, should they be able to have it deleted ? In the following, I want to explain my opinion on censorship in libraries. If some parents see a book that offends them and they think their kids shouldn't be able to get it from the library, they might just forbid them to read it. I don't think they should be able to take it off, although they might think other kids shouldn't be able to get it either, but that's not their decision. Each parent has to decide for themselves whether they want their kids to get certain books, but a parent shouldn't be able to decide for everyone by removing a book. Does that person have the right to say that a book should be taken down? It is their personal opinion that they don't like it, but by deleting it they would also prevent other people from reading it, and that is not fair. Different people like different books and are offended by different books, so if everyone removed a book they didn't like from the library, there would be no more books. I think if someone is offended by a book, they just shouldn't read it. They could tell their friends and family not to read it, because they thought it was offensive, but in the end, each would have to decide for themselves. I also think that when the library does not have certain books, because they are really careful about the books they take from their library, that should be enough for others. Does censorship solve the problems? If one person wants to censor something in a library, there's bound to be another person on the other side of this argument trying to protect that work from being taken down. As a free country, every individual has the right to adopt any form of literature or music that they find enjoyable, and history has shown the world that censorship leads those in power down a path dark. Protection from offensive content is only necessary and fair when the impressionable young minds of the youth of the world are involved, but once a person is old enough to make informed decisions, it should be their prerogative to choose. its own content. Censorship is unacceptable because of human rights and how it has affected history, but necessary to protect young people. A person has the right to choose the type of literature he wishes to read. If someone doesn't like a book and gets banned from a library, then everyone will want a book they don't like banned. Take the example of a hypothetical public library : a public library is an open and free place where men, women and children of all backgrounds can come to learn and have fun with a good book, magazine or music. . A great mental image of serenity and peace. How does this image appear to a viewer once the books start to disappear from the shelves ? Suddenly, right and left, books disappear as if by magic: a ceratin book is frowned upon by mothers, a religious group does not like the message that book sends, and this book makes people sad. Before long, there aren't many books left in this hypothetical library other than books for toddlers. With this system, everyone suffers. Everyone must keep their right to read what they want. Everything would be easier if books were simply not banned in libraries. History has given the world many cruel dictators. Often, once in power, it is not the most popular form of government. To keep his subjects under his domination, he often had to resort to the suppression of civil rights. It could be a curfew, bogus elections, or censorship. If the leader has the power of censorship, he or she can control what the public thinks, feels and believes. With this power over them, the people are weakened and often mistreated. Now imagine that the censorship is happening in a country that has civil rights. People wouldn't take it. So why start censorship in an area that promotes freedom? Censorship is absolutely not necessary and, as history has shown, it is certainly not a good thing. Censorship is unacceptable in any form in a free country that promotes civil rights. There is, however, another element at play here: the protection of youth and innocence. Almost anyone can remember a time when he was young and innocent, without worry or trouble. It can go away in an instant. Children should not be exposed to things inappropriate for their age. Almost every movie these days contains some violent and risky material, if not full-fledged adult. The age of innocence is getting younger with each generation and children are conditioned to this material to an extreme extent. A statement like this @ MONTH1 sounds hypocritical from someone against censorship, but it's not "censorship" when you protect young people. Because of personal rights and what history has shown the world, censorship should never be tolerated except for the protection of children. It is each person's choice of what they would like to read and absorb, so their choices should not be violated. The world has seen time and time again what censorship can do to people. In addition, children must be protected, and this is not censorship. Censorship doesn't solve any problem, but it makes everyone miserable. Therefore, why censor

Don't you want your community library to be a place where kids can learn and have fun? Unfortunately, some libraries have offensive reading material, movies, music, etc. It is the responsibility of library employees to place such offensive material in the adult reading section of the building. Parents must tell their children that the adult section is prohibited and library employees must prevent children from being in this restricted area. These @ MONTH1 articles are offensive to some people, and they @ MONTH1 are too inappropriate for children. However, some readers have the right to consult these documents if they wish. That's why they shouldn't be taken off the shelves completely, just taken out of the rest of the books, music, movies, etc. I'm not the type to deny anyone their rights. If there is to be adult reading material in a community library, it should be in an area where children are not allowed. It's just courtesy, and everyone has to cooperate. Author Katherine Paterson once commented, “We can all think of a book that we hope none of our children or other children have pulled off the shelves. But if I have the right to take this book off the shelf - this job that I hate - then you also have the exact same right and everyone else too. And then we don't have any more books on the shelf for any of us ”. Many in society share Katherine's point of view, while some believe in strict library censorship. It is important not to infringe the rights of others, restrict freedom of expression or limit their knowledge. Therefore, I support his sentiment. If the material is considered inappropriate for children, or others for that matter, then censorship should be implemented in the home by the parents, and not by a public institution. America was founded on the need for freedom: freedom of speech, religion and the press. If we start to change that or limit the press that a library may or may not have, we are destroying the core values of a nation. Can we turn our backs on what our ancestors knew we were entitled to? Also, if we start pulling a few “ offensive ” books off the shelves, where do we draw the line ? Anyone can claim that almost any book is "offensive" in one way or another, that doesn't mean we should immediately remove it from the shelves of a major public institution. If you don't want to take my word for it, come back to histroy. What kind of civilization was @ LOCATION1 ? Not the one you want to live in, I guess. Almost no one would, and one of the things they controlled the most was personal freedom. They started off with the seemingly minor act of censoring books. First, it was just considered unsavory to have a book that they found offensive, in this case it was the work of the authors @ CAPS1, @ CAPS2- @ CAPS3 or @ CAPS4. Later, they started to burn these books and punish people for having them in their possession. If we are to live in a country, where a man has the rights he should have, then we cannot censor library books. This seemingly innocuous act could have far greater consequences than expected. Many families have different values that they want to pass on to their children, morals that they hope to teach them. The problem is that the boundaries and values of each family are unique; We can't just assume anything about families in general. I personally know a family that is very protective of what their children read, watch or listen to. On the other hand, I know a family which leaves more freedom to its children to choose what they read. What a group of parents wants to prevent their child from reading @ MONTH1 varies from another group of parents. If they find material that they don't want their children to read, then they should censor at home. They could start with a discussion of why the material is inappropriate and make the child responsible for obeying their parents. It helps parents become more involved in their children's lives and helps children develop personally with responsibility and respect. In the end, it all comes down to freedom. Do we want to live in a country with freedom of the press and the right to access it publicly. My answer is yes, and I think that is also the answer of my colleague @ CAPS5. We can't clearly draw the line between " offensive " and " okay " because we are all different. Therefore, we cannot lower our opinions on the public institution, but on the home. It is not fair to limit an entire society to what it has access to by virtue of one opinion.

Libraries have always been an exceptional source of information. Among the myriad of ingenious materials provided by libraries are books, films and magazines. Recently, the debate over whether libraries should censor offensive material has caused quite a stir. Many parents argue that they don't want their children exposed to explicit materials, especially books, on display in public libraries. Others responded to this statement by saying that if every book deemed offensive was taken off the shelves, the shelves would be nearly empty. Author Katherine Paterson said, " We can all think of a book that we hope none of our kids took off the shelves - that job I hate - then you have the exact same right and everyone else too." . And then we don't have any more books on the shelves for any of us ”(Katherine Paterson). Offensive books should not be removed from libraries for the simple reason that they remain one of the most trusted sources of historical information and events, and without books society would suffer. The most important reason why people shouldn't be allowed to remove shocking books from shelves is that if everyone was allowed to remove a book they found shocking, there wouldn't be many books left on the shelves of people. libraries. . There are many historical books that contain offensive images and content, but people should ignore this because these books are stories of our history. Without them, society would forget the past events that shaped and shaped our world into the world it is today. A further important reason for the censorship of libraries is wrong is that the material that a person finds offensive @ @ month1 month1 is not for another. Each person has their own perspective on certain topics and events. For this reason, the censorship of a certain book should not be reduced to the opinion of an individual. Rather, the decision to remove a certain book from the library shelves should come from the opinion of a large group of individuals. In so doing, a fair representation of @ CAPS1, most books are intended to tell fictional stories or historical events which are not meant to offend anyone. Fiction books are meant to fill the mind of the reader with stories and mental images of a story created by the author. Additionally, historical books are meant to capture events from our past so that people @ MONTH1 can remember those events now and in the future. Overall, the idea of censoring libraries is a negative proposition. The books were meant to provide historical narratives and fictional stories to enrich the minds of readers, not to poison them with bad content. Everyone has their own opinions, which is why people should learn to respect the opinions of different books, no matter how offensive the @MO11 material is to them.

Dear @ ORGANIZATION1, @ CAPS1 I was growing up in my tiny little neighborhood, life couldn't have been easier. For children, life is about eating, sleeping, playing and laughing. Their innocent minds don't reflect on the meaning of life or love, but curiosity grabs every child from time to time. With stubborn persistence, a child would likely go to the ends of the earth to figure out what confidential information he heard his parents talk about. But @ CAPS1 does harmless curiosity mean destroying a child's innocence ? By viewing material intended for adults, such as books in a library, children can acquire premature knowledge that can interfere with their development. However, libraries shouldn't be afraid to fill their shelves with books suitable for adults, because an author spends countless hours writing this book, this book is a part of the history of the human race, and everyone @ MONTH1 cannot find inappropriate content. Authors have the freedom to write about anything that interests them, and taking away their right to post their thoughts and opinions is unfair. A censored author must feel like a basketball player who has failed despite hours of training. So an author who has practiced and honed his writing skills does so in the hope of publishing his work. Disagreeing with someone's interest in a topic is no reason to exclude their precious thoughts from society. Books that are suitable for adults deserve to be presented to adults as the author intended. Every piece of literature that has ever been written documents some part of the history of the human race. Even fictional novels serve as monuments to the depths of human imagination. Therefore, no book should be censored, no matter how inappropriate the material is. Just as remembering @ CAPS2 has influenced mankind not to repeat the mistakes of the past, keeping books of the most gruesome content @ MONTH1 saves authors from repeating such dishonorable content. In other words, if censorship removes " mistakes " from literature on library shelves, that is, an oblivious author will not repeat that " mistake ". By remembering these mistakes, humanity will be able to move forward in literature. The @ CAPS1 books are not " mistakes ", they recall the highlights of literature. All literature, appropriate and inappropriate, is a piece of human history that should not be kept secret. Finally, who should judge what constitutes an “error” in literature? A book on @ CAPS3 @ MONTH1 would be inappropriate in the eyes of a @ CAPS4, but this @ MONTH1 book would be sacred for an @ CAPS5. Beauty is in the eye of the beholder. In addition, for a given book, there is at least one person who does not agree with its message. A library is built for the education of the public, not for the interests of one person. If someone is offended by a work of literature, maybe they should just move on and find a book more suited to their interests. The decision on a novel's relevance is up to the reader, not the government, the library, or the activist group. Censorship of material in libraries would deprive authors of their chance to let their works be seen by others, keep the records of the human race a secret, and deprive the reader of the privilege of deciding what is appropriate. Authors endure long hours of practice and writing in order to be read in their minds, and such a motive should not be taken away from them. Each book represents an aspect of human life and records it for future generations to avoid previous mistakes. And these "mistakes" are made by the reader, a decision the censorship makes on itself. Instead of choosing which books are seen by the public, perhaps libraries should just create an adults-only section to house the "controversial" books; as a result, mankind would remain educated and free, and children would remain innocent. - @ ORGANIZATION2

This system separates all books, magazines, music and movies into their own genres. For example, if you are looking for a mystery book, you will find it in the non-fiction section. This system helps people find exactly what they are looking for. If people are offended by a certain genre, they don't have to come into contact with it. This system is a better way to find exactly what you want instead of stumbling across a book or movie that you find offensive. Almost all libraries use this system so that they do not have to use a censor. Everywhere we go, someone somewhere is going to find something offensive. It is fundamentally part of our human nature. As a place used to acquire knowledge and wisdom, a library is a wonderful resource. Several varieties of @ MONTH1 books can be found in a local library, from sci-fi documentaries to just fiction. The most amazing part of a library is the fact that an @ MONTH1 chooses what it reads. Yet if a man objects to a book's point of view and believes that a certain book should be taken out of the library, then the freedom of choice is lost. Reading selection should be open to all readers, and although some @ MONTH1 would disagree, heavy library censorship is an unnecessary measure that restricts the ability to acquire knowledge. In today's society, many people differ in taste or gender. So much so that it is sometimes difficult to find common ground in a large group. The Library is a place where people @ MONTH1 can enjoy their differences, reading different types of books spread over many shelves. Still, if a person doesn't like a book, their opinion shouldn't influence the book's withdrawal because of their preference. Author Katherine Paterson made a wise point on the idea of censorship, saying, "If I have the right to take this book off the shelf - this work that I hate - then you have exactly the same right and everyone too. And then we have no books' (no pag.). If a person finds a work that is vulgar and thinks it should be removed from the library, then what is stopping another person from removing a book they don't like ? If severe censorship is allowed in libraries, then libraries will become diminished resources, containing only a few documents. Yet censorship of age-specific documents is necessary in libraries. Allowing a child to read or watch an inappropriate movie or book is inexcusable. However, the censorship of children's books does not mean the suppression of such books. Removing a book from the shelves of a library is just as bad as allowing a child to read a book that is too mature for his age. Katherine Paterson said, “ We can all think of a book that we hope none of our children or other children have taken off the shelves. But ... then we don't have any more books on the shelf for any of us. ' (no pag.). Censorship of books in a library cannot lead to the removal of the books that have shaped our society and our ideas, even if it is to protect a child. A middle ground must be found between true censorship and the stubborn suppression of books, for the sake of one's own life. This will help not only libraries but also society. There are many different opinions in modern society and due to the differences in beliefs and ideas, people will sometimes disagree. However, it is important that people agree to allow themselves the choice. A very important choice that every individual makes on a daily basis is what to read. Libraries allow people to make their choices and help expand their knowledge in the process. Literature, whether in a library or at home, should never be rejected because of someone else's opinion. Censorship of libraris should be considered, but not at the expense of knowledge. Libraries should not be censored.

I believe that some documents should not be taken off the shelves of a library. Libraries are supposed to provide people with the various media that they need. This action will result in three things: business loss, inconvenience, and a narrowing of people's book selection. The number one reason libraries shouldn't be censored is that they won't lose customers. Just like any other industry, libraries need people to use their multimedia material, such as: books, magazines, music, etc. in order to stay in business. The point that a lot of people go to the library is to get certain magazines, or movies, and so on, and to get rid of certain movies and / or magazines is to get rid of certain users. Another reason is that the loss of business will result in the loss of clients, and if there are no clients to view the multimedia documents, the library will be closed. No one wants their library closed, so libraries shouldn't be censored. In addition, parents, instead of having an entire library censored, censor what children receive from libraries. Everyone has a different take on something, which is what started this problem in the first place. When everyone learns to get along, maybe this problem can be solved then.

Everything in life can have a double meaning, which makes it easier to find offensive material. These few chosen reasons explain why censorship in libraries is unnecessary. Libraries are places where people can go to step outside of the norm and get lost in the works of other authors and musicians. I believe reading and the ability to express yourself through the powers of music is a very essential part of our lives. Censoring them would only shelter our lives and prevent the younger generations from discovering the effect words have on our emotions and day-to-day actions. Books are one of the oldest forms of information we have had over the years. I think if someone deleted information that they found offensive, it would only open the door for other people to find excuses to keep the hard work of the authors behind closed doors. Personally, I like to read. I think with every book I read, it opens the door to other beliefs and cultures that I would never have learned otherwise. Children need to be able to explore the world, to know how other civilizations are growing and functioning and how we in @ LOCATION1 function in our own little world which is becoming more and more critical every day. The only way to do that is to pick up a book from someone who has been lucky enough to experience it for themselves. I have always had a deep passion for music. When I want to relax, music helps me focus and open my mind. In my opinion, music censorship shouldn't even be something people consider. Removing music from libraries is hard for me to start trying and accepting. Freedom of speech was once a big part of our country. Now it seems everything we were taught from our big @ LOCATION2 was nothing more than a fake blanket to let the government control how we live, act and now how we choose to express ourselves. . Music is a liberating way to express yourself in a not-so-violent way. In the sixties and seventies, music was how many people protested against things like war and racism without being violent. Times have changed, however, and officials in our country no longer see it as an “ appropriate ” option . I believe that just because a company thinks something is wrong does not mean that it really is. We already care enough about what other people think, why try to judge the work of others if we cannot accept the fact that we are all different. If we all accepted the differences between the cultures of our world, there would be no debate about whether or not to censor an expressive and emotional work of art that is worth showing in our libraries.

We find some slurs and words offensive, while others @ MONTH1 are not. @ NUM1 years old, when I was in @ NUM2, my class @ CAPS1 was reading a story on the '@ CAPS2 @ CAPS3 @ CAPS4'. There were @ CAPS4 young black kids struggling to get a respected education in a white school. Times were tough then and there was still a lot of racism at @ LOCATION2. While my teacher read this book to us every day, we all sat down and listened taciturn. After the third day of reading this book, we all sat down as usual ready to finish the book. Five minutes after class started while the teacher was reading the book, she read and spoke every word in the book. In the middle of the sentence, it was written “nigger-lover”, and the professor didn't hesitate a bit as he said it. Within @ MONEY1, @ NUM3 black kids walked out of the room screaming curses at the top of their lungs. This teacher did not realize that she had offended these children by what she considered to be just reading in class. The book '@ CAPS2 @ CAPS3 @ CAPS4' has not been censored in any way. Although many children watched it and thought some of the conditions were harsh, no one ever thought there would ever be a riot at school. Many types of people go to libraries looking for different things. Blocking content types will lose the audience's interest and they will go elsewhere. Now that doesn't mean offensive materials are okay and here's why. There should be an intensity level in which the element is offensive. Blasphemy and action are minor types of offense. However, intense violence and explicit materials such as blood and the like must have conditions. Categorization is an acceptable method of preventing some @ CAPS1 from viewing harmful material. Placing violent books in a blocked @ CAPS1 area of less than @ NUM1 is an effective way to restrict children. Adults would not want to enter this section and therefore would not be a problem. It is understandable that some people are offended by the material displayed in libraries because a library is a place for everyone. If the offensive items were only available to those who wanted them and hidden from the public, then this is something that might solve the problem. Many people should realize that a library is not a place for one type of person and should be shared by all types. When it comes to books, they can be placed in areas available for people who appreciate it. The same goes for magazines and movies. Cinema is a form of entertainment that receives heavy media coverage in magazines and books. Any advertising that shows explicit material or offensive images or text should be removed from public view. These advertisements should only be visible to the audience for which they are intended. If @ CAPS1 wants to use computers, rules must also be applied. @ CAPS1 under @ NUM1 should have safety precautions that prevent them from using the computer to scan for harmful material, @ CAPS1 over @ NUM1 knows how to avoid certain content and do so at their own risk. These computers should be kept separate to prevent children or anyone who finds the depleting material from peering. Listening to music on the computer or through a device should also require a few elements. If there is a song that is not preferable to a certain audience or that offends someone, headphones should be a requirement. The library is a place of peace and quiet, so headphones are still needed. This can potentially eliminate the problem as long as the headphones themselves are at an appropriate level. If @ CAPS1 wants to check out any material that is or may be offensive or explicit in some way, he must prove his age of maturity, as some articles with mild violence are available for @ CAPS1 under @ NUM1 . In conclusion, if the categorization of harmful or explicit content is placed correctly and out of sight of viewers or unwanted children, it can eliminate the problem. Music should be played through headphones only and should be at an appropriate volume. No item should be taken off the shelves if it offends people, but the conditions should be met. With rules and conditions, the library can be a safe and enjoyable place for everyone.
